Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mini Notched Turbine (MiNT) is suited to address the emerging technology market for miniaturized energy harvesting generators, which can offer a reliable and sustainable source of power to implantable, sensing or monitoring device systems. There have been several research efforts and resources geared toward continuous, sustainable, and efficient miniaturized power sources for implantable devices, micro systems multisystem (bio, chemical, environmental) sensors, and wearable and portable electronics. Particularly for implantable devices, these initiatives seek to address the need for an alternative and/or replacement for batteries, which have limited lifetime and require repeated surgeries. In the United States there are approximately 400,000 implants performed per year and more than 3 million patients with implanted cardiac devices, many requiring some type of power source that supplies a continuous power and requires little maintenance to work. The proposed system presents an important solution by replacing the battery of an implantable medical device that would otherwise have to be removed every 5 years on average. This solution will ultimately benefit the end-users or patients who are most affected by the current system. A profile of the typical customer of the proposed innovation would be biomedical device companies, healthcare providers (hospitals, doctors/surgeons), medical patients, and/or manufacturers of miniature generators. The mini notched turbine technology has the potential to address the frequency of repeatable implantable medical device (IMD) surgeries, power multiple IMDs, and impact the quality of life for patients while addressing the need for continuous power generation/delivery.

The goal of the project is to design, produce and test a prototype of an energy harvesting device capable of converting fluid flow kinetic energy to electrical energy by use of electromagnetic induction. This energy harvesting system has a wide scope since it can extract energy from gas flow lines, fuel lines, water pipes and even the blood stream in a higher mammal or from any environment where there is fluid flow energy present. The potential contribution of the proposed system is, to produce a paradigm shift in the manufacture and use implantable medical devices which will eventually reduce the cost burden to hospitals, insurance companies and ultimately patients. This will also reduce the risk of repeated surgeries, anxiety and pain to patients that have been implanted with a life-saving device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Affordable and reliable alternative energy systems are constantly being investigated for medical, aerospace, automotive, and household applications.   One of the technology requirements for these systems is providing ultra-low power (10-100 micro watts), which pushes the limits of current technologies and existing solutions.  The National Academy of Engineering, in its Grand Challenges, emphasizes the need to help consumers acquire new energy sources that are continuous, sustainable, and generate efficient electricity.  Therefore, new techniques and creative designs are required to meet urgent requirements of today's cutting edge devices.

 

This work has created an innovation in turbine designs for alternative energy generation systems.  A patented mini notched turbine (MiNT, Figure 1) allows for increased rotor speed, optimized ultra-low power management circuit integration, and improvement in the DC-DC converter efficiency.  The efficiency of the power management circuit has been improved by 10% compared with conventional power management circuits over a wide range of input power, allowing harvesting more power and delivery to a load.  

 

Generated power measurements (Figure 2) obtained from MiNT over a range of generator speeds (500-2250 rpm) are measured with different values of resistance loadings. It is observed that the MiNT can generate up to 7.5 mW at average speeds and up to 38.8 mW at high generator speeds, compared to 27.4 mW from non-notched ones, which is 35% higher. These maximum values can be obtained under impedance matching conditions.

 

Modern turbine systems are increasingly required to satisfy needs of portable devices, medical, and biomedical systems, but the most important goal is improving environmental compatibility and adaptability without detriment to the performance. There are limitations in the use of micro turbines when the application demands special characteristics, such as constant pressure, input and output size and shape, total immersion in a microfluidic system, and adaptability to be used in different positions. Traditional impulse turbines, such as Pelton and Banki, have a fixed orientation and position, and do not require pressure around the rotor chamber, because the fluid jet is created by the nozzle prior to reaching blades; in general the fluid is in free flow after blades are impacted.

 

A novel mini notched turbine addresses limitations presented above. The MiNT system fulfills a different function compared to the Banki and Pelton structures. The special casing and mini notched turbine blades are designed to optimize the amount of fluid injected at the inlet, contain and control the pressure of working fluid through the turbine, and maintain volumetric pressure on the surface of the blades that are not receiving the initial fluid stream directly (Figure 3).  The turbine system is made up of two parts, the turbine casing and the rotor.

 

Key Findings

  • Increased efficiency was achieved by changing the inclination angle of the nozzle
  • Large hub diameter and blade attachment helped reduce vortices and increase internal pressure and system efficiency
  • Increased clearance between blades and casing walls  helped to promote cross flow continuity, favorable impulse-reaction conditions, and increase internal pressure

 

The MiNT design is not limited to ultra-low power applications and can easily be extended to extend the battery life for portable systems. The MiNT could be used as a green energy source that converts biomechanical energy, from some kind of microfluidic flow, to electrical energy.

The design of this novel turbine is developed with environmental and biomedical applications in mind.  Materials, size, and the assembling of parts are critical issues in the design and final assembly of prototypes. In addition, bio-systems could be developed, if the system is built with biocompatible materials, transforming it into a bio micro turbine with the possibility to be used in medical devices as part of a system implanted in a living organism.  Through this work several graduate (3), undergraduate (2) students have contributed to the securing of one patent and five publications.

 

The further development of MiNT technologies will be essential for harvesting power for miniaturized systems, alternative energy sourcing, and extended battery life for various applications (Figure 4). The Mini Notched Turbine (MiNT) is a new sustainable, cost effective, and multi-faceted power source that can change how the world gains access to energy for diverse systems.
